data.text:
By AMY LONGSDORF; Times Leader Correspondent

Sunday, June 13, 1999 Page: 1G

NEW YORK- Madeleine Stowe’s fondest childhood memory explains a lot about

why she decided to end her four-year hiatus from Hollywood movies with the new

John Travolta military thriller “The General’s Daughter”

“I used to live for `Welcome Back, Kotter,” says the actress. “It was my

favorite TV show. I not only wrote John fan letters, I actually pretended to

be a journalist when I was 16 so I could interview him on the set. It didn’t

work out, but I got as far as getting his publicist on the phone, which seemed

pretty thrilling at the time.”

Things were even more thrilling on the set of “The General’s Daughter,” a

murder mystery in which Stowe plays an Army investigator teaming up with

Travolta to solve a slaying. (The movie opens Friday in area theaters.) In

between discovering high-level cover-ups and top-secret videotapes, the pair

manage to find time to generate oodles of sexual tension.

Originally, the movie, which is based on a Nelson DeMille bestseller,

featured an even more explicit Travolta/Stowe relationship. But in the editing

room, director Simon West (“Con Air”) decided the complicated connection kept

getting in the way of the enfolding mystery.

“The love affair between John and me belonged in a different movie.

It began to upstage the drama of the story, but take my word for it, we

shot some great love scenes,” raves Stowe. Exactly how great? “Just remember

that (Travolta’s wife) Kelly Preston was originally cast in my role, and she

and John requested them.”

Even when they weren’t shooting love scenes, Stowe had a terrific time

working with Travolta on the movie’s Savannah set. Temperatures regularly

soared above 100 degrees, but the former Sweathog never lost his cool.

“John was so nice to every single person on the set that one day I said to

him, `God, why don’t you just knock it off! No one is that nice!’ ” says Stowe

during an interview in New York’s Parker Meridian Hotel. “But he is that nice.

He was nice every single day for four months. I was very suspicious at first.

But I’ve learned you can’t hide your real self that long.”

It was Travolta who hand-picked the actress for the role after Preston

dropped out. Watching “Last of the Mohicans” and “Blink” back-to-back

convinced him to go with Stowe.

“Besides being gorgeous, Madeleine has the intensity of a Meryl Streep and

the ability as an artist to think in character,” says Travolta.

“She can find the truth in any line of dialogue. It’s remarkable to watch

her work.”

Lately, work has been the last thing on Stowe’s mind. Ever since she and

actor-husband Brian Benben (TV’s “Dream On”) bought a 400-acre ranch in the

hill country outside San Antonio, the actress has been reluctant to leave her

home on the range. Besides roles in the little-seen “Playing By Heart” and

“The Proposition,” she hasn’t been on screen since co-starring opposite Bruce

Willis in “12 Monkeys.”

“It’s hard to leave home when you’re so happy there,” she says. “The ranch

is so great. It’s a big operation with cattle, horses and sheep.”

Does the actress actually get up at the crack of dawn to do chores? “I ride

every morning,” she replies. “I work the land. OK, not really. Just make up

whatever you want. Just make me sound good.”

Stowe might not work the land, but she does keep busy. Three years ago, she

gave birth to her first child, a daughter named May, who has inherited her

mother’s feisty personality.

“She’s hilarious,” says Stowe, 40. “The other day, I snapped at my husband

because I was pulling off some boots of mine that were too small and somehow

it was his fault. My daughter snapped back at me, `Mommy, Daddy is sad. Leave

him alone.’

“She took his side! She’s only 3, but the other day she told me, `Mommy, if

you yell at Daddy again I’m gonna kick your ass.’ I didn’t know where it came

from and then I realized she was watching too much TV.”

Growing up in Eagle Rock, Calif., the daughter of a civil service engineer

father an a Costa-Rican housewife mom, Stowe was something of a television

fanatic. When her dad contracted multiple sclerosis, the actress found herself

withdrawing even further into a fantasy world of TV and movies.

“I couldn’t bring kids to the house anymore because suddenly my father had

a violent temper,” she says.

Even though she found success as a performer almost immediately, it wasn’t

until she met her future husband on the set of TV’s “The Gangster Chronicles”

that Stowe believes she came out of her shell.

“I was 22, and I only dated one person prior to Brian and that was, believe

it or not, Dennis Quaid. You know, my husband was the second person I ever had

sex with, and the first one was a lot older than me so I don’t consider him a

date.

“When I met Brian, he was just wild. He’d do anything. Say anything. I

didn’t know how to talk, so his freedom was so sexy to me. I was so shy, and

he brought me out of my shell. He had no choice. I couldn’t go any deeper into

my shell. I had to come out.

“It’s funny. Brian remembers when he first met me that he turned to the

show’s director and said, `What is her problem?’ I was so quiet that he

thought I had an attitude or something.”

Stowe isn’t as quiet these days. One of Hollywood’s most outspoken stars,

she clashed with director Jonathan Kaplan about the ending of “Unlawful

Entry,” tussled with 20th Century Fox over the firing of “Bad Girls” director

Tamra Davis and is now embroiled in a small battle with Miramax over the fate

of her next film, “Impostor,” which was originally designated as one-third of

a trilogy.

“At the moment, they’re trying to turn `Impostor’ into a full-length film,”

she says. “It began as part of a movie called `Alien Love Triangle.’ Danny

Boyle did the first film, and then Gary Fleder did the second one, which is

called `Impostor.’ And Miramax is so in love with it, they’re trying to push

us all into a movie version of it this fall. But unless it’s the right script,

I say why mess with something that’s perfect.”

At least Stowe’s life in Texas remains on an even keel. Most of the time.

“To this day I can’t wait to see Brian again,” she says. “I go out for

groceries thinking, `I can’t wait to get home to see my husband.’ Of course,

sometimes I’m really mean and nasty to him, but he still loves me.”

Stowe’s career has a way of working itself out too. Since making her film

debut in “Stakeout,” the actress has managed to hold her own with some of

Hollywood’s heaviest hitters, including Jack Nicholson (“The Two Jacks”),

Kevin Costner (“Revenge”), Tim Robbins (“Short Cuts”), Bruce Willis (“12

Monkeys”) and Daniel Day-Lewis (“The Last of the Mohicans”).

Stowe stops short of naming her favorite co-star but Day-Lewis ranks near

the top of the list.

“Do you remember the waterfall love scene Daniel and I had in `Mohicans’?”

asks Stowe. “We did it once and I asked to do it again. I said, `I don’t think

it went well.’ And they believed me! So we shot it a couple more times. Yes, I

know. I am a very lucky woman.”
